column16: description
column17: comments

column16: The user-defined name for the sample.
column17: Store the collector sample ID. If this number is considered identifiable information, provide an alternative ID. Be sure to store the key that maps between the original and alternative IDs for traceability and follow up if necessary. Every collector sample ID from a single submitter must be unique. It can have any format, but we suggest that you make it concise, unique and consistent within your lab.

column16: The user-defined identifier assigned to a portion of the original sample.
column17: Store the ID for the subsample/aliquot.

column16: The user-defined identifier assigned to a combined (pooled) set of samples.
column17: If the sample being analyzed is the result of pooling individual samples, rename the pooled sample with a new identifier. Store the pooled sample ID.

column16: The user-defined identifier assigned to a genome reconstructed from metagenomic data.
column17: Store the MAG ID.

column16: The user-defined project name assigned to a sequencing project.
column17: If the sample was collected or analyzed under the umbrella of a specific project, include the name of that project here.

column16: The INSDC (i.e., ENA, NCBI, or DDBJ) accession number of the BioProject(s) to which the BioSample belongs.
column17: Store the BioProject accession number. BioProjects are an organizing tool that links together raw sequence data, assemblies, and their associated metadata. Each province will be assigned a different bioproject accession number by the National Microbiology Lab. A valid NCBI BioProject accession has prefix PRJN e.g., PRJNA12345, and is created once at the beginning of a new sequencing project.

column16: The identifier assigned to a BioSample in INSDC (i.e., ENA, NCBI, or DDBJ) archives.
column17: Store the accession returned from the BioSample submission. NCBI BioSamples will have the prefix SAMN.

column16: The versioned identifier assigned to an assembly or consensus sequence in GenBank archives.
column17: Store the versioned GenBank accession assigned to the submitted sequence.

column16: The Sequence Read Archive (SRA) identifier linking raw read data, methodological metadata and quality control metrics submitted to the INSDC.
column17: Store the accession assigned to the submitted sequence. NCBI-SRA accessions start with SRR.

column16: The identifier assigned to a sequence in GISAID (the Global Initiative on Sharing All Influenza Data) archives.
column17: Store the accession assigned to the submitted sequence. GISAID accessions start with EPI.

column16: The user-defined GISAID virus name assigned to the sequence.
column17: GISAID virus names should be in the format "hCoV-19/Country/Identifier/year".

column16: The identifier assigned to a BioSample in ENA (European Nucleotide Archive) archives.
column17: Store the accession assigned to the submitted sequence. ENA accessions start with SAMEA.

column16: The identifier assigned to a sequence in DDBJ (DNA Data Bank of Japan) archives.
column17: Store the accession assigned to the submitted sequence. DDBJ accessions start with SAMD.

column16: The identifier assigned to a BioSample in DRA (DDBJ Sequence Read Archive) archives.
column17: Store the accession assigned to the submitted sequence. DRA accessions start with DRA.

column16: The identifier assigned to a BioSample in GSA (Genome Sequence Archive) archives.
column17: Store the accession assigned to the submitted sequence. GSA accessions start with CRA.

column16: The identifier assigned to a sequence in Enterobase archives.
column17: Store the barcode assigned to the submitted sequence. Enterobase barcodes start with different 3 letter codes depending on the organism.

column16: The user-defined identifier assigned to a specific location from which samples are taken.
column17: Store the ID for the site from which a sample was taken. The "site" is user defined (e.g. it may be a building and its environs, a specific entity within an environment). Please use the same site ID for all samples from a given site, regardless of when these samples were taken. Any important changes in site location, should be represented with a new site ID.

column16: The user-defined identifier assigned to a specific event during which one or more samples are taken, from one or more sites.
column17: Store the ID for the event during which a sample or samples were taken. For example, an event could be one person taking samples from multiple sites, or multiple people taking samples from one site.

column16: The name of the individual at the organization that collected the original sample that plays a data governance role and oversees how a sample and associated contextual data is used and distributed.
column17: Provide the name of the sample collection data steward.

column16: The name of the organization with which the sample collector is affiliated.
column17: The name of the agency should be written out in full, (with minor exceptions) and be consistent across multiple submissions.

column16: The email address of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sample.
column17: The email address can represent a specific individual or lab e.g. johnnyblogs@lab.ca, or RespLab@lab.ca

column16: The country of origin of the sample.
column17: If known, select a value from the pick list.

column16: The state/province/territory of origin of the sample.
column17: Provide the state/province/territory name from the GAZ geography ontology. Search for geography terms here: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/ga

column16: The county/region of origin of the sample.
column17: Provide the county/region name from the GAZ geography ontology. Search for geography terms here: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/gaz

column16: The city of origin of the sample.
column17: Provide the city name from the GAZ geography ontology. Search for geography terms here: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/gaz

column16: The name of a specific geographical location e.g. Credit River (rather than river).
column17: Provide the name of the specific geographical site using a specific noun (a word that names a certain place, thing).

column16: The latitude coordinates of the geographical location of sample collection.
column17: Provide latitude coordinates if available. Do not use the centre of the city/region/province/state/country or the location of your agency as a proxy, as this implicates a real location and is misleading. Specify as degrees latitude in format "d[d.dddd] N|S".

column16: The longitude coordinates of the geographical location of sample collection.
column17: Provide longitude coordinates if available. Do not use the centre of the city/region/province/state/country or the location of your agency as a proxy, as this implicates a real location and is misleading. Specify as degrees longitude in format "d[dd.dddd] W|E".

column16: The availability status of a shapefile descriping the catchment contributing to a watershed.
column17: Select a value from the picklist to describe whether or not a watershed shapefile would be available upon request.

column16: The name of the watershed shapefile.
column17: Provide the shapefile filename corresponding to the watershed from which the sample was taken. If there are multiple files associated with the watershed, provide all names separated by commas.

column16: Taxonomic name of the organism.
column17: Provide the official nomenclature for the organism present in the sample. Search for taxonomic names here: ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/taxonomy.

column16: The reason that the sample was collected.
column17: The reason a sample was collected may provide information about potential biases in sampling strategy. Provide the purpose of sampling from the picklist in the template. Most likely, the sample was collected for Public health surveillance. The reason why a sample was originally collected may differ from the reason why it was selected for sequencing, which should be indicated in the "purpose of sequencing" field.

column16: The range of locations or entities sampled expressed in general terms.
column17: Provide the scale of wastewater sampling by selecting a value from the picklist.

column16: The date on which the sample was received.
column17: Provide the sample received date in ISO 8601 format, i.e. "YYYY-MM-DD".

column16: The date on which the sample was collected.
column17: Sample collection date is critical for surveillance and many types of analyses. Required granularity includes year, month and day. If this date is considered identifiable information, it is acceptable to add "jitter" by adding or subtracting a calendar day (acceptable by GISAID). Alternatively, ”received date” may be used as a substitute. The date should be provided in ISO 8601 standard format "YYYY-MM-DD".

column16: The date on which the sample was processed.
column17: Provide the sample processed date in ISO 8601 format, i.e. "YYYY-MM-DD". The sample may be collected and processed (e.g. filtered, extraction) on the same day, or on different dates.

column16: The time at which the sample was collected.
column17: If a sample was collected over a certain time period, provide the end time here and the duration of the collection in the field "sample collection duration value". Provide this time in ISO 8601 24hr format, in your local time.

column6: sample collection time of day menu
column16: The descriptive time of day during which the sample was collected.
column17: If known, select a value from the pick list. The time of sample processing matters especially for grab samples, as fecal concentration in wastewater fluctuates over the course of the day.

column16: The amount of time over which the sample was collected.
column17: Provide the numerical value of time.

column16: The units of the time duration measurement of sample collection.
column17: Provide the units from the pick list.

column16: The activities or variables upstream of sample collection that may affect the sample.
column17: If there was an activity that would affect the sample prior to collection (this is different than sample processing), provide the activities by selecting one or more values from the template pick list. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The details of the activities or variables that affected the sample collected.
column17: Briefly describe the presampling activities using free text.
column18: Agricultural waste from large farm contributes waste to the site sampled.

column16: The numerical value of the volume measurement of the sample collected.
column17: Provide the numerical value of volume.

column16: The units of the volume measurement of the sample collected.
column17: Provide the units from the pick list.

column16: The process used to store the sample.
column17: Provide details of how the sample was stored from time of collection until time of processing. If there were issues with the cold chain storage, note those here.
column18: The sample was placed in a tube in a cooler bag during transportation (~3 hours) to the lab site. At this point the sample was placed in storage medium and put in a -10C freezer until it was processed and extracted 5 days later.

column16: The medium in which a sample is stored.
column17: Provide the name of the transport medium or storage medium used for this sample. If none was used, leave blank or write "None".

column16: The numerical value of the time measurement during which a sample is in storage.
column17: Provide the numerical value of time.

column16: The units of a measured sample storage duration.
column17: Provide the units from the pick list.

column16: Any processing applied to the sample during or after receiving the sample.
column17: Select processes from the picklist that were applied to this sample.

column16: The details of the processing applied to the sample during or after receiving the sample.
column17: Briefly describe the processes applied to the sample.

column16: An environmental location may describe a site in the natural or built environment e.g. contact surface, metal can, hospital, wet market, bat cave.
column17: Provide a descriptor of the environmental site sampled. Use the picklist provided in the template. If not applicable, choose a null value.

column16: A substance obtained from the natural or man-made environment e.g. soil, water, sewage.
column17: Provide a descriptor of the environmental material sampled. Use the picklist provided in the template. If not applicable, choose a null value.

column16: The properties, characteristics and qualities of a substance obtained from the natural or man-made environment.
column17: Provide the environmental material properties by selecting descriptors from the pick list.

column16: The type or classification of a wastewater system e.g. sanitary sewer, combined sewer
column17: Provide the classification of the wastewater system by selecting from the provided pick list.

column16: The type of control used in the experiment.
column17: This field is used to distinguish samples under study from controls. A sample may act as an experimental control if it is used to detect experimental errors or to ensure experimental methods are performing as expected. If the sample acted as an experimental control, select an experimental control type from the picklist. If the sample was not a control, leave blank or select "Not Applicable".

column16: The details regarding the experimental control contained in the sample.
column17: Provide details regarding the nature of the reference strain used as a control, or what is was used to monitor.
column18: Human coronavirus 229E (HCoV-229E) spiked in sample as process control

column16: The instrument or container used to collect the sample e.g. grab sampler.
column17: Provide a descriptor if a device was used for sampling. Use the picklist provided in the template. If not applicable, choose a null value.

column16: The process used to collect the sample.
column17: Provide a descriptor if a collection method was used for sampling. Use the picklist provided in the template. If not applicable, choose a null value.

column16: The process used to extract genomic material from a sample.
column17: Briefly describe the extraction method used.

column16: The kit used to extract genomic material from a sample
column17: Provide the name of the genomic extraction kit used.

column16: The description of the endogenous controls included when extracting a sample.
column17: Provide the names of endogenous controls that were used as a reference during extraction. If relevant, include titers of these controls, as well as whether any controls were expected but not identified in the sample.

column16: The recovery efficiency of an extraction, calculated as the amount of a synthetic or endogenous compound identified in the sample relative to the amount expected.
column17: Provide value as a percent.

column16: The method by which recovery efficiency of an extraction was calculated.
column17: Provide a brief description of how extraction recovery efficiency was measured or estimated.

column4: water catchment area human population measurement value
column16: The numerical value of the human population measurement that contributes to the composition of water in a catchment area.
column17: Where known, provide the numerical value of population size, i.e. the number of people.

column4: water catchment area human population range
column6: water catchment area human population range menu
column16: The human population range of the water catchment that contributes effluent to a wastewater site.
column17: Where catchment population is not well known, provide an estimation of population size by selecting a value from the picklist.

column4: water catchment area human population measurement method
column16: The method by which a water catchment 's human population size was measured or estimated
column17: Provide a brief description of how catchment population size was measured or estimated.
column18: population of jurisdiction encompassing the wastewater service area

column4: water catchment area human population density value
column16: The numerical value describing the number of humans per geographical area in a water catchment.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the population density in the catchement area.

column4: water catchment area human population density unit
column6: water catchment area human population density unit menu
column16: The unit describing the number of humans per geographical area in a water catchment.
column17: Provide the unit of the population density in the catchement area.

column16: A type of area that is populated by humans to different degrees.
column17: Provide the populated area type from the pick list.

column16: The state of the atmosphere at a place and time as regards heat, dryness, sunshine, wind, rain, etc.
column17: Provide the weather conditions at the time of sample collection.

column16: Weather conditions prior to collection that may affect the sample.
column17: Provide the weather conditions prior to sample collection.

column16: The amount of water which has fallen during a precipitation process.
column17: Provide the quantity of precipitation in the area leading up to the time of sample collection.

column16: The units of measurement for the amount of water which has fallen during a precipitation process.
column17: Provide the units of precipitation by selecting a value from the pick list.

column16: The process used to measure the amount of water which has fallen during a precipitation process.
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or method used to measure precipitation.
column18: Rain gauge over a 12 hour period prior to sample collection

column16: The numerical value of a measurement of the ambient temperature.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured temperature.

column16: The units of a measurement of the ambient temperature.
column17: Provide the units of the measured temperature.

column16: The measured pH value indicating the acidity or basicity(alkalinity) of an aqueous solution.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured pH.

column16: The process used to measure pH value.
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure pH.

column4: total daily flow rate measurement value
column16: The numerical value of a measured fluid flow rate over the course of a day.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured flow rate.

column4: total daily flow rate measurement unit
column6: total daily flow rate measurement unit menu
column16: The units of a measured fluid flow rate over the course of a day.
column17: Provide the units of the measured flow rate by selecting a value from the pick list.

column4: total daily flow rate measurement method
column16: The process used to measure total daily fluid flow rate.
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure flow rate.

column16: The numerical value of a measured instantaneous fluid flow rate.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured flow rate.

column6: instantaneous flow rate measurement unit menu
column16: The units of a measured instantaneous fluid flow rate.
column17: Provide the units of the measured flow rate by selecting a value from the pick list.

column16: The process used to measure instantaneous fluid flow rate.
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure flow rate.

column16: The numerical value of a measurement of turbidity.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured turbidity.

column16: The units of a measurement of turbidity.
column17: Provide the units of the measured turbidity by selecting a value from the pick list.

column16: The process used to measure turbidity.
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure turbidity.

column16: The numerical value of a measurement of dissolved oxygen.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured dissolved oxygen.

column16: The units of a measurement of dissolved oxygen.
column17: Provide the units of the measured dissolved oxygen by selecting a value from the pick list.

column16: The method used to measure dissolved oxygen.
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure dissolved oxygen.
column18: Dissolved oxygen meter in vertical direction

column16: The numerical value of a measurement of oxygen reduction potential (ORP).
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured oxygen reduction potential.

column6: oxygen reduction potential (ORP) measurement unit menu
column16: The units of a measurement of oxygen reduction potential (ORP).
column17: Provide the units of the measured oxygen reduction potential by selecting a value from the pick list.

column16: The method used to measure oxygen reduction potential (ORP).
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure oxygen reduction potential.

column16: The measured value from a chemical oxygen demand (COD) test.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the COD test result.

column6: chemical oxygen demand (COD) measurement unit menu
column16: The units associated with a value from a chemical oxygen demand (COD) test.
column17: Provide the units of the COD test result.

column16: The method used to measure chemical oxygen demand (COD).
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure COD.

column4: carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand (CBOD) measurement value
column16: The numerical value of a measurement of carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand (CBOD).
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured CBOD.

column4: carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand (CBOD) measurement unit
column6: carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand (CBOD) measurement unit menu
column16: The units of a measurement of carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand (CBOD).
column17: Provide the units of the measured CBOD by selecting a value from the pick list.

column4: carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand (CBOD) measurement method
column16: The method used to measure carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand (CBOD).
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure CBOD.

column16: The numerical value from a total suspended solids (TSS) test.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured TSS.

column6: total suspended solids (TSS) measurement unit menu
column16: The units associated with a value from a total suspended solids (TSS) test.
column17: Provide the units of the measured TSS.

column16: The method used to measure total suspended solids (TSS).
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure TSS.

column16: The numerical value from a total dissolved solids (TDS) test.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured TDS.

column17: Provide the units of the measured TDS.

column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure TDS.
column18: Subtract calculated TSS from calculated TS

column16: The numerical value from a total solids (TS) test.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured TS.

column16: The units associated with a value from a total solids (TS) test.
column17: Provide the units of the measured TS.

column16: The method used to measure total solids (TS).
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure TS.
column18: Gravimetric method by oven drying, then weighing

column16: The numerical value of a measurement of alkalinity.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured alkalinity.

column16: The units of a measurement of alkalinity.
column17: Provide the units of the measured alkalinity.
column18: milligram per liter of calcium carbonate (mg/L CaCO3)

column16: The process used to measure alkalinity.
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure alkalinity.

column16: The numerical value of a measurement of conductivity.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured conductivity.

column16: The units of a measurement of conductivity.
column17: Provide the units of the measured conductivity.

column16: The method used to measure conductivity.
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure conductivity.

column16: The numerical value of a measurement of salinity.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured salinity.

column16: The units of a measurement of salinity.
column17: Provide the units of the measured salinity.

column16: The method used to measure salinity.
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure salinity.

column16: The numerical value of a measurement of total nitrogen (TN).
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured TN.

column16: The units of a measurement of total nitrogen (TN).
column17: Provide the units of the measured TN.

column16: The method used to measure total nitrogen (TN).
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure TN.

column16: The numerical value of a measurement of total phosphorus (TP).
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured TP.

column16: The units of a measurement of total phosphorus (TP).
column17: Provide the units of the measured TP.
column18: milligrams orthophosphate as phosphorus per liter (mg PO4-P/L)

column16: The method used to measure total phosphorus (TP).
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure TP.

column16: A gene, virus, bacteria, or substance used to measure the sanitary quality of water in regards to fecal contamination.
column17: If a fecal contamination indicator was measured, select it from the picklist.

column16: The numerical value of a measurement of fecal contamination.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured fecal contamination.

column16: The units of a measurement of fecal contamination.
column17: Provide the units of the measured fecal contamination.

column16: The method used to measure fecal contamination.
column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure fecal contamination.

column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured fecal coliforms.

column16: The units of a measurement of fecal coliforms.
column17: Provide the units of the measured fecal coliforms.

column17: Provide the name of the procedure or technology used to measure fecal coliforms.

column17: If a urinary contamination indicator was measured, select it from the picklist.

column16: The units of a measurement of urinary contamination.
column17: Provide the units of the measured urinary contamination.

column16: The numerical value of a measurement of temperature of a sample at collection.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured temperature.

column16: The units of a measurement of temperature of a sample at the time of collection.
column17: Provide the units of the measured temperature.

column16: The numerical value of a measurement of temperature of a sample upon receipt.
column17: Provide the numerical value of the measured temperature.

column16: The units of a measurement of temperature of a sample at the time upon receipt.
column17: Provide the units of the measured temperature.

column16: The reason that the sample was sequenced.
column17: The reason why a sample was originally collected may differ from the reason why it was selected for sequencing. The reason a sample was sequenced may provide information about potential biases in sequencing strategy. Provide the purpose of sequencing from the picklist in the template. The reason for sample collection should be indicated in the "purpose of sampling" field.

column16: The description of why the sample was sequenced providing specific details.
column17: Provide an expanded description of why the sample was sequenced using free text. The description may include the importance of the sequences for a particular public health investigation/surveillance activity/research question. Suggested standardized descriptions include: Assessing public health control measures, Determining early introductions and spread, Investigating airline-related exposures, Investigating remote regions, Investigating health care workers, Investigating schools/universities.

column16: The name of the agency that submitted the sequence to a database.
column17: The name of the agency should be written out in full, (with minor exceptions) and be consistent across multiple submissions. If submitting specimens rather than sequencing data, please put the "National Microbiology Laboratory (NML)".

column16: The email address of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sequence.
column17: The email address can represent a specific individual or laboratory.

column16: The date the sample was sequenced.
column17: ISO 8601 standard "YYYY-MM-DD".

column16: The user-specified identifier for the library prepared for sequencing.
column17: The library name should be unique, and can be an autogenerated ID from your LIMS, or modification of the isolate ID.

column16: The platform technology used to perform the sequencing.
column17: Provide the name of the company that created the sequencing instrument by selecting a value from the template pick list. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The model of the sequencing instrument used.
column17: Provide the model sequencing instrument by selecting a value from the template pick list. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The name of the DNA library preparation kit used to generate the library being sequenced.
column17: Provide the name of the library preparation kit used.

column16: The protocol or method used for sequencing.
column17: Provide the name and version of the procedure or protocol used for sequencing. You can also provide a link to a protocol online.

column16: The length of the DNA fragment generated by mechanical shearing or enzymatic digestion for the purposes of library preparation.
column17: Provide the fragment length in base pairs (do not include the units).

column16: The specifications of the primers (primer sequences, binding positions, fragment size generated etc) used to generate the amplicons to be sequenced.
column17: Provide the name and version of the primer scheme used to generate the amplicons for sequencing.

column16: The length of the amplicon generated by PCR amplification.
column17: Provide the amplicon size, including the units.

column16: The name of the method used to assess whether a sequence passed a predetermined quality control threshold.
column17: Providing the name of the method used for quality control is very important for interpreting the rest of the QC information. Method names can be provided as the name of a pipeline or a link to a GitHub repository. Multiple methods should be listed and separated by a semi-colon. Do not include QC tags in other fields if no method name is provided.

column16: The version number of the method used to assess whether a sequence passed a predetermined quality control threshold.
column17: Methods updates can make big differences to their outputs. Provide the version of the method used for quality control. The version can be expressed using whatever convention the developer implements (e.g. date, semantic versioning). If multiple methods were used, record the version numbers in the same order as the method names. Separate the version numbers using a semi-colon.

column16: The determination of a quality control assessment.
column17: Select a value from the pick list provided. If a desired value is missing, submit a new term request to the PHA4GE QC Tag GitHub issuetracker using the New Term Request form.

column16: The reason contributing to, or causing, a low quality determination in a quality control assessment.
column17: Select a value from the pick list provided. If a desired value is missing, submit a new term request to the PHA4GE QC Tag GitHub issuetracker using the New Term Request form.

column16: The details surrounding a low quality determination in a quality control assessment.
column17: Provide notes or details regarding QC results using free text.
column18: CT value of 39. Low viral load. Low DNA concentration after amplification.

column16: The names of the software and version number used for raw data processing such as removing barcodes, adapter trimming, filtering etc.
column17: Provide the software name followed by the version e.g. Trimmomatic v. 0.38, Porechop v. 0.2.3

column16: The method used to remove host reads from the pathogen sequence.
column17: Provide the name and version number of the software used to remove host reads.

column16: The name of the software used to assemble a sequence.
column17: Provide the name of the software used to assemble the sequence.
column18: SPAdes Genome Assembler, Canu, wtdbg2, velvet

column16: The version of the software used to assemble a sequence.
column17: Provide the version of the software used to assemble the sequence.

column16: The name of the software used to generate the consensus sequence.
column17: Provide the name of the software used to generate the consensus sequence.

column16: The version of the software used to generate the consensus sequence.
column17: Provide the version of the software used to generate the consensus sequence.

column16: The percentage of the reference genome covered by the sequenced data, to a prescribed depth.
column17: Provide value as a percent.

column16: The average number of reads representing a given nucleotide in the reconstructed sequence.
column17: Provide value as a fold of coverage.

column16: The threshold used as a cut-off for the depth of coverage.
column17: Provide the threshold fold coverage.

column16: The percentage of expected genes identified in the genome being sequenced. Missing genes indicate missing genomic regions (incompleteness) in the data.
column17: Provide the genome completeness as a percent (no need to include units).

column16: The number of total base pairs generated by the sequencing process.
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The total number of non-unique reads generated by the sequencing process.
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The number of unique reads generated by the sequencing process.
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The threshold used as a cut-off for the minimum length of a read after trimming.
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The number of contigs (contiguous sequences) in a sequence assembly.
column17: Provide a numerical value.

column4: percent Ns across total genome length
column16: The percentage of the assembly that consists of ambiguous bases (Ns).
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The number of ambiguous bases (Ns) normalized per 100 kilobasepairs (kbp).
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The length of the shortest read that, together with other reads, represents at least 50% of the nucleotides in a set of sequences.
column17: Provide the N50 value in Mb.

column16: The percent of the total number of reads identified as contamination (not belonging to the target organism) in a sequence dataset.
column17: Provide the percent contamination value (no need to include units).

column16: The length of the genome generated by assembling reads using a scaffold or by reference-based mapping.
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: The length of the genome defined by the most common nucleotides at each position.
column17: Provide a numerical value (no need to include units).

column16: A persistent, unique identifier of a genome database entry.
column17: Provide the accession number of the reference genome.

column16: The method used to remove duplicated reads in a sequence read dataset.
column17: Provide the deduplication software name followed by the version, or a link to a tool or method.

column16: The name of the software used to map sequence reads to a reference genome or set of reference genes.
column17: Provide the name of the read mapping software.

column16: The version of the software used to map sequence reads to a reference genome or set of reference genes.
column17: Provide the version number of the read mapping software.

column16: The name of the taxonomic reference database used to identify the organism.
column17: Provide the name of the taxonomic reference database.

column16: The version of the taxonomic reference database used to identify the organism.
column17: Provide the version number of the taxonomic reference database.

column16: A description of the criteria used to map reads to a reference sequence.
column17: Provide a description of the read mapping criteria.

column16: A description of the overall bioinformatics strategy used.
column17: Further details regarding the methods used to process raw data, and/or generate assemblies, and/or generate consensus sequences can. This information can be provided in an SOP or protocol or pipeline/workflow. Provide the name and version number of the protocol, or a GitHub link to a pipeline or workflow.

column16: The name of the gene used in the diagnostic RT-PCR test.
column17: Provide the full name of the gene used in the test. The gene symbol (short form of gene name) can also be provided. Standardized gene names and symbols can be found in the Gene Ontology using this look-up service: https://bit.ly/2Sq1LbI

column16: The binary value of the result from a diagnostic test.
column17: Select a value from the pick list provided, to describe whether a target was determined to be present or absent within a sample.

column16: The value of the result from a diagnostic test.
column17: Provide the numerical result of a diagnostic test (no need to include units).

column16: The unit of the result from a diagnostic test.
column17: Select a value from the pick list provided, to describe the units of the given diagnostic test.

column16: The method by which a diagnostic result was received.
column17: Select a value from the pick list provided to describe the method used for a given diagnostic test.

column16: Names of individuals contributing to the processes of sample collection, sequence generation, analysis, and data submission.
column17: Include the first and last names of all individuals that should be attributed, separated by a comma.
column18: Tejinder Singh, Fei Hu, Joe Blogs

column16: The DataHarmonizer software and template version provenance.
column17: The current software and template version information will be automatically generated in this field after the user utilizes the "validate" function. This information will be generated regardless as to whether the row is valid of not.
